messages.text:
I have a few questions, that perhaps are more general and basic than this channel, so I’m sorry if this is the wrong place to ask:

I’m trying to implement neural CDE/ continuous time RNNs and I’ve got a basic, sluggish implementation running. The core of it is a `NeuralODE`-like struct that when called runs the following function
```function (n::RNNODE)(X::DataInterpolations.LinearInterpolation,  u₀, p=n.p)

    tstops = eltype(n.u₀).(collect(X.t))

    dudt_= let re=n.re, x=X, preprocess=n.preprocess
      (u,p,t) -> re(p)(u, preprocess(X(t)))
    end

    ff = ODEFunction{false}(dudt_,tgrad=basic_tgrad)
    prob = ODEProblem{false}(ff,u₀,getfield(n,:tspan),p)
    solve(prob,n.args...;sense=n.sense, tstops=tstops, n.kwargs...)
end```
where `n.preprocess` is some function mapping an array to another array (e.g. permuting dimensions)

Q 1) Is it always a good idea to use a `let` lock in cases like these as opposed a closure?
Q 2) No matter what I try I keep hints from the profiler that the line `(u,p,t) -> re(p)(u, preprocess(X(t)))`   is dynamically dispatched.  I’m not sure what I could do to avoid the dynamic dispatch. The preprocessing function is specified once, when the `RNNODE` constructor is used, after it’s constant for each solver step and each mini-batch.

messages.text: how is the type defined?

it’s a poor re-purposing of your code :smile:
```struct RNNODE{M<:AbstractRNNDELayer,P,RE,T,A,K,I,S} <: NeuralDELayer
    model::M
    p::P
    re::RE
    tspan::T
    args::A
    kwargs::K
    sense
    in::I
    hidden::I
    preprocess
    #extendedstates::S

    function RNNODE(model,tspan, args...;p = nothing, preprocess = identity,
        sense = InterpolatingAdjoint(autojacvec=ZygoteVJP()), append_input=false, kwargs...)
        _p,re = destructure(model)
        nhidden = size(model.Wᵣ,2)
        nin = size(model.Wᵢ,2)
        if isnothing(p)
            p = _p
        end

        new{typeof(model),typeof(p),typeof(re),
            typeof(tspan),typeof(args),typeof(kwargs),
            typeof(nin), append_input}(
            model,p,re,tspan,args,kwargs,sense,nin,
            nhidden, preprocess)
    end
end```

elements.text: it’s a poor re-purposing of your code

struct RNNODE{M<:AbstractRNNDELayer,P,RE,T,A,K,I,S} <: NeuralDELayer
    model::M
    p::P
    re::RE
    tspan::T
    args::A
    kwargs::K
    sense
    in::I
    hidden::I
    preprocess
    #extendedstates::S

    function RNNODE(model,tspan, args...;p = nothing, preprocess = identity,
        sense = InterpolatingAdjoint(autojacvec=ZygoteVJP()), append_input=false, kwargs...)
        _p,re = destructure(model)
        nhidden = size(model.Wᵣ,2)
        nin = size(model.Wᵢ,2)
        if isnothing(p)
            p = _p
        end

        new{typeof(model),typeof(p),typeof(re),
            typeof(tspan),typeof(args),typeof(kwargs),
            typeof(nin), append_input}(
            model,p,re,tspan,args,kwargs,sense,nin,
            nhidden, preprocess)
    end
end

messages.text: the lack of the type on preprocess is the issue

elements.text: the lack of the type on preprocess is the issue

messages.text: it needs a type parameter

So I need to convert the ODEs to Julia. But can I still use diffeqpy for solving the ODEs?
Yeah. There's a caveat with the GPU stuff needing to be defined on the Julia side because we need to recompile it for GPUs, but you can still call the solver from diffeqpy if that part has been done.

elements.text: Yeah. There's a caveat with the GPU stuff needing to be defined on the Julia side because we need to recompile it for GPUs, but you can still call the solver from diffeqpy if that part has been done.

messages.text: yes, use a `ContinuousCallback` and use the `terminate!(integrator)` function from the Integrator interface <@U7ZNTQFLH>
there's an example on the callbacks and event handling page.

messages.text:
Hi,

I want to have  sparse matrix of Laplacian with periodic boundary conditions. I tried DiffEqOpe but this does not work

```function DiffOp(N, lx)
	hx = 2lx/N
	# D   = CenteredDifference(2, 2, hx, N)
	D2x = CenteredDifference(2, 2, hx, N)
	Qx = PeriodicBC(typeof(hx))
	Δ = sparse(D2x * Qx)
	return Δ
end
	DiffOp(100, 1.)```
Is it not supposed to work like that?

elements.text:

	# D   = CenteredDifference(2, 2, hx, N)
	D2x = CenteredDifference(2, 2, hx, N)
	Qx = PeriodicBC(typeof(hx))
	Δ = sparse(D2x * Qx)
	return Δ
end
	DiffOp(100, 1.)
Is it not supposed to work like that?

I often face the issue of declaring the type of something  that is not known at compile time. A  bad example is to save the eigenvectors of an operator. Depending on the method, they have different type. But you dont know it until you compute it so I have to precompute  it and send it to the data for saving. This feels clunky. I am not sure I describe the thing well, partly because I manage to get  around this but I am not satisfied. I can feel it if I addd more utilities, I have to change my structs.

elements.text: I often face the issue of declaring the type of something  that is not known at compile time. A  bad example is to save the eigenvectors of an operator. Depending on the method, they have different type. But you dont know it until you compute it so I have to precompute  it and send it to the data for saving. This feels clunky. I am not sure I describe the thing well, partly because I manage to get  around this but I am not satisfied. I can feel it if I addd more utilities, I have to change my structs.

messages.text: New here and not sure if I am right here with this question, but I am trying to create an `ODESystem` in  `ModelingToolkit.jl` using a for loop like so: ``` parnames = ["k1", "k2"] for parname in parnames        @parameters parname end  k1 ERROR: UndefVarError: k1 not defined ```  I think this is wrong on several levels (including for loop scoping). Does anyone have an idea how I can use strings with the `@parameter` macro in a for loop (or otherwise know where to ask this question best)? Thanks!

text.text:
New here and not sure if I am right here with this question, but I am trying to create an `ODESystem` in  `ModelingToolkit.jl` using a for loop like so:
```
parnames = ["k1", "k2"]
for parname in parnames
       @parameters parname
end

k1
ERROR: UndefVarError: k1 not defined
```

I think this is wrong on several levels (including for loop scoping). Does anyone have an idea how I can use strings with the `@parameter` macro in a for loop (or otherwise know where to ask this question best)?
Thanks!

messages.text: It might be a bug

I'm looking to solve a problem with a SVector-backed ComponentArray with Rodas5, but getting the error below. SVector alone or Array-backed ComponentArray are fine, but the combo breaks (Julia 1.6, StaticArrays v1.0.1 / OffsetArrays v1.5.3 / OrdinaryDiffEq v5.50.2). Any suggestions for the glue code I need? MWE:
```julia> f(u,p,t) = 1.01*u
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> u0 = ComponentVector{SVector{2}}(x=1, y=2)
ComponentVector{SVector{2, Int64}}(x = 1, y = 2)

julia> tspan = (0.0,1.0)
(0.0, 1.0)

julia> prob = ODEProblem(f,u0,tspan)
ODEProblem with uType ComponentArray{Int64, 1, SVector{2, Int64}, Tuple{Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}}} and tType Float64. In-place: false
timespan: (0.0, 1.0)
u0: (x = 1, y = 2)

julia> sol = solve(prob, Rodas5(), reltol=1e-8, abstol=1e-8)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching lu!(::ComponentArray{Float64, 2, Matrix{Float64}, Tuple{Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}, Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}}}, ::Val{true}; check=false)```

elements.text: I'm looking to solve a problem with a SVector-backed ComponentArray with Rodas5, but getting the error below. SVector alone or Array-backed ComponentArray are fine, but the combo breaks (Julia 1.6, StaticArrays v1.0.1 / OffsetArrays v1.5.3 / OrdinaryDiffEq v5.50.2). Any suggestions for the glue code I need? MWE:

julia> f(u,p,t) = 1.01*u
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> u0 = ComponentVector{SVector{2}}(x=1, y=2)
ComponentVector{SVector{2, Int64}}(x = 1, y = 2)

julia> tspan = (0.0,1.0)
(0.0, 1.0)

julia> prob = ODEProblem(f,u0,tspan)
ODEProblem with uType ComponentArray{Int64, 1, SVector{2, Int64}, Tuple{Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}}} and tType Float64. In-place: false
timespan: (0.0, 1.0)
u0: (x = 1, y = 2)

julia> sol = solve(prob, Rodas5(), reltol=1e-8, abstol=1e-8)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching lu!(::ComponentArray{Float64, 2, Matrix{Float64}, Tuple{Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}, Axis{(x = 1, y = 2)}}}, ::Val{true}; check=false)

messages.text: Wait, sorry, Array-backed ComponentArray doesn't work, so I guess this is generally a question of how to make ComponentArray and Rodas5 work together.

elements.text: Wait, sorry, Array-backed ComponentArray doesn't work, so I guess this is generally a question of how to make ComponentArray and Rodas5 work together.

messages.text: <@UUMJUCYRK> So it works with an Array-backed ComponentArray but not SVector? This is somewhat odd considering that the error you posted is describing a missing dispatch for a ComponentArray with backing array of type `Matrix{Float64}` . Regardless, I suspect this could potentially have something to do with `SVector` being immutable (no `setindex!` ).

ODEProblem with uType ComponentVector{Float64,typename(SArray)...} and tType Float64. In-place: false
